content.raw: Why `EXPECT_ANY_THROW` before `EXPECT_THROW`?
content.html: Why EXPECT_ANY_THROW before EXPECT_THROW?

content.raw: Good question, I don't actually know.  The old test did that, and I just pulled it forward and replicated it.  Doing a short bit of archaeology, it looks like this test has been like this since @scpeters put it in originally.  @scpeters, any particular reason for this construct?
content.html: Good question, I don't actually know. The old test did that, and I just pulled it forward and replicated it. Doing a short bit of archaeology, it looks like this test has been like this since @scpeters put it in originally. @scpeters, any particular reason for this construct?

content.raw: nitpick: `if (_splitter.empty())` might be imperceptibly more efficient.
content.html: nitpick: if (_splitter.empty()) might be imperceptibly more efficient.

content.raw: Yeah, you are absolutely right.  I did a quick test locally, and .empty() is like twice as fast as == "".  In the general case it won't matter, but no reason not to use it here.  I'll change this.
content.html: Yeah, you are absolutely right. I did a quick test locally, and .empty() is like twice as fast as == "". In the general case it won't matter, but no reason not to use it here. I'll change this.

content.raw: Nitpick: after asserting the size is 2 the next two checks could be EXPECT_EQ. If there was a bug the extra output from both EXPECT_EQ might help with solving it.
content.html: Nitpick: after asserting the size is 2 the next two checks could be EXPECT_EQ. If there was a bug the extra output from both EXPECT_EQ might help with solving it.

content.raw: Good point.  Looking at this closer, I should probably split these up into individual tests; that way, if one of the ASSERTs fails, the rest of the tests will still run.  I'll go ahead and do that.
content.html: Good point. Looking at this closer, I should probably split these up into individual tests; that way, if one of the ASSERTs fails, the rest of the tests will still run. I'll go ahead and do that.

content.raw: Does trim strip other white space characters like `\r` `\n` `\t`?

content.raw: Currently it only trims space and tab (if I remember properly, that was what the original boost implementation did as well).  I'll add a test for trimming tabs as well.
content.html: Currently it only trims space and tab (if I remember properly, that was what the original boost implementation did as well). I'll add a test for trimming tabs as well.

content.raw: Can we use a `std::unique_ptr` instead of a raw pointer?
content.html: Can we use a std::unique_ptr instead of a raw pointer?

content.raw: Yeah, good point.  We were actually a little inconsistent here, in that *most* things are using unique_ptr, but Param.hh (which is what I modelled this after) did not.  I've now switched both Filesystem.hh and Param.hh over to using unique_ptr.
content.html: Yeah, good point. We were actually a little inconsistent here, in that most things are using unique_ptr, but Param.hh (which is what I modelled this after) did not. I've now switched both Filesystem.hh and Param.hh over to using unique_ptr.

content.raw: You're right. We originally started implementing PIMPL with raw pointers, although we're using `std::unique_ptr` a while ago for new private classes (which I believe is preferable).
content.html: You're right. We originally started implementing PIMPL with raw pointers, although we're using std::unique_ptr a while ago for new private classes (which I believe is preferable).

content.raw: Yeah, that's fine.  I've also now converted Element over to using std::unique_ptr, which I think is the last holdout.
content.html: Yeah, that's fine. I've also now converted Element over to using std::unique_ptr, which I think is the last holdout.

content.raw: Can we use a `std::unique_ptr` instead of a raw pointer?
content.html: Can we use a std::unique_ptr instead of a raw pointer?

content.raw: I'm a little less certain on this one (mostly because of me being unfamiliar with unique_ptr).  If I make this a unique_ptr, can I still assign to it from a C function (like we do in the Unix side), and can I still reinterpret_cast<> it?
content.html: I'm a little less certain on this one (mostly because of me being unfamiliar with unique_ptr). If I make this a unique_ptr, can I still assign to it from a C function (like we do in the Unix side), and can I still reinterpret_cast<> it?

content.raw: I didn't realize this is a `void *`. I don't think you can declare a `void` `unique_ptr`, although I believe is possible with a `shared_ptr` but in this case the semantics of a `shared_ptr` and the overhead are not a good fit. I'd leave it as it is. (You could do the reinterpret_casts by using the `.get()` function).
content.html: I didn't realize this is a void *. I don't think you can declare a void unique_ptr, although I believe is possible with a shared_ptr but in this case the semantics of a shared_ptr and the overhead are not a good fit. I'd leave it as it is. (You could do the reinterpret_casts by using the .get() function).

content.raw: `const std::string &`?
content.html: const std::string &?

content.raw: Yeah, good point.  Fixed now.
content.html: Yeah, good point. Fixed now.

content.raw: Consider to rename this member variable to `dataPtr` for consistency.
content.html: Consider to rename this member variable to dataPtr for consistency.

content.html: Yeah, I did that, and I also renamed the DirIterInternal class to DirIterPrivate to be consistent.

content.raw: This private class definition should live in the `.cc` for implementing PIMPL properly, right?
content.html: This private class definition should live in the .cc for implementing PIMPL properly, right?

content.raw: Yeah, that would be classic PIMPL.  However, none of the sdformat implementations actually do this.  We should probably be consistent and do them all at once.
content.html: Yeah, that would be classic PIMPL. However, none of the sdformat implementations actually do this. We should probably be consistent and do them all at once.

content.raw: Oh, I see why.  All of the other users have templated functions in the header files, so they must have the *Private classes defined there.  Filesystem isn't like that, so I'll move it into the .cc file.
content.html: Oh, I see why. All of the other users have templated functions in the header files, so they must have the *Private classes defined there. Filesystem isn't like that, so I'll move it into the .cc file.

content.raw:
I just noticed a build on yakkety say that `readdir_r` is deprecated:

* https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/sdformat-ci-default-yakkety-amd64/23/warnings21Result/
content.html:
I just noticed a build on yakkety say that readdir_r is deprecated:

  • https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/sdformat-ci-default-yakkety-amd64/23/warnings21Result/

content.raw:
Ug, this is going to make life difficult: http://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man3/readdir_r.3.html

Apparently as of glibc 2.24, readdir(3) is now thread-safe, and thus readdir_r(3) is deprecated.  However, that is not true on earlier versions of glibc.  So we may have to do some version detection thing here to figure out which version to use, and I don't know what the case on other Unix (i.e. MacOS) is.  Would you mind opening a new issue about this, since it will require some investigation.  Thanks.
content.html:
Ug, this is going to make life difficult: http://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man3/readdir_r.3.html

Apparently as of glibc 2.24, readdir(3) is now thread-safe, and thus readdir_r(3) is deprecated. However, that is not true on earlier versions of glibc. So we may have to do some version detection thing here to figure out which version to use, and I don't know what the case on other Unix (i.e. MacOS) is. Would you mind opening a new issue about this, since it will require some investigation. Thanks.
